thread.title: The victims of the 'catastrophic' Essendon DFO plane crash
thread.title_full: The victims of the 'catastrophic' Essendon DFO plane crash

title: The victims of the 'catastrophic' Essendon DFO plane crash

organizations.name: ny daily news mr de haven

text:
The victims of the 'catastrophic' Essendon DFO plane crash By 9NEWS From top left, clockwise: Pilot Max Quartermain, Glen Garland, Russel Munsch and Greg De Haven. (Facebook/Supplied) 
A pilot and four US golfers preparing to visit one of Australia’s leading golf courses took off from Essendon Airport yesterday, but never made it to their destination. 
As family members, Melburnians and Americans reel from Victoria’s worst aviation disaster in 30 years, detail about those killed is beginning to be revealed. The men were on a golf trip from America at the time. (Facebook) 
The group was on a celebratory trip to the other side of the world from Austin, Texas. Max Quartermain. (Supplied) 
MAX QUARTERMAIN 
An experienced Australian pilot, 63-year-old Max Quartermain was the co-owner of Corporate and Leisure Aviation. He had 38 years of flying experience and was described by Australian Corporate Jets chief executive Bas Nikolovski as “one of the most experienced pilots”. 
Alongside his wife Cilla, the couple operated the business from their home in Rye, on Victoria’s Mornington Peninsula. Steve Atto, who had flown with Mr Quartermain, said he was extremely diligent and “truly a nice guy”. 
Friend Pamela Taylor echoed the sentiment, adding she would forever cherish “very special memories of Max Quartermain”. “A wonderful work mate, friend and boss,” she wrote. It’s been revealed Mr Quartermain was under investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau for a near-miss in 2015 . Glenn Garland. (Supplied) 
GLENN GARLAND 
Glenn Garland retired as CEO of an energy consulting company CLEAResult in 2015, according to the Austin Business Journal. He continued to invest and engage in management consulting in Austin, Texas. 
Mr Garland had expressed his excitement on social media for the group’s dream golfing getaway. He marvelled at Melbourne being “one magnificent and amazing city”, and posted updates to his Facebook page on various golf courses around the country. 
At the time, he was touring New Zealand and Australia with his wife and friends. CLEAResult co-founder Jim Stimmel described Mr Garland in a statement as “more than a colleague... he was a visionary and a close friend”. Greg De Haven. (Facebook) 
GREG DE HAVEN 
Greg De Haven, an avid golfer, regularly posted his thoughts on various golf courses such as Royal Melbourne and Kingston Health in New Zealand to his social media pages. 
The 70-year-old was a former FBI agent and US army veteran, his sister Denelle Wicht told the New York Daily News . Ms Wicht paid tribute to her “handsome athletic big brother” who was killed “on his once in a lifetime trip to Australia”. 
Her friends were quick to rally around her and the De Haven family, offering messages of love and support. She told NY Daily News Mr De Haven was “a man’s man” who leaves behind his wife Laurie, three children and six grandchildren. Russel Munsch. (Facebook) 
RUSSEL MUNSCH 
Mr Munsch was a founding partner of Texas-based law firm, Munsch Hardt which was involved in a number of prominent bankruptcy cases in the US, including the Enron proceedings. 
The firm said in a statement that Mr Munsch was retired but was “one of the best of all time”. A relative of Mr Munsch, Carol Holst, posted an image of the pair together on Facebook, reminding her followers “hug your loved ones. You never know”. 
JOHN WASHBURN 
The Austin Business Journal named the fourth victim as retiree John Washburn, who was also Mr Munsch’s neighbour. The Statesman reported Mr Washburn was a former executive and general counsel at Sammons Enterprises in Dallas.
